If the fires get much worse I hope the insurance companies can cover all the losses.  I heard some people say there were houses that cost upwards of $10 million but there were also cases of houses that had their insurance policies canceled due to fire risk.  It's just that if 1,000 homes are completely destroyed, insurance claims could be in the hundreds of millions.  I don't think most insurance companies could quickly come up with that amount of money and even if they do, it will probably be the last time they would offer policies to any homeowners in those fire-prone areas.  I never thought those fires could reach down into the residential areas in Los Angeles but with the strong winds blowing embers for miles it seems it can happen.  The more area the fire covers, the fire fighters become thinned out.  How many hours can a fire fighter go without rest or sleep while fires keep popping up.  That's a scary scenario that no one is prepared for.
I had wondered why no airdrops were being done but I didn't know they couldn't fly in heavy wind.  They need to drop fire-retardant to stop houses from easily igniting from sparks.  Four major fires all in different areas will be hard to control with limited resources.
Land developers really packed buildings in tight and in tough places to defend.

The phones aren't working at the facility and my mom's phone lost battery so I can't get in contact and I'm watching all of this from New Jersey. I just hope they contain this fire before it comes down the mountain to the surrounding buildings even more.

I only worked emergency relief once long ago and am not a professional by any means, but I am intelligent enough to know that all I am likely to contribute in such a situation is to make things worse, so I stay home and watch on YouTube (unless I needed to evacuate and, hopefully, I had the means to do so before it was too late).

The story of the family in Altadena escaping the Eaton fire is truly a painful reminder of the fragility of life in the face of natural disasters. Their courage in the face of danger is commendable, but it also raises larger questions about preparedness and early warning for communities in hazardous areas. Is there a way to improve the emergency response system so that other families do not have to face such life-and-death moments?

That is what happened here in Butte county 6 years ago starting one of the worst and deadliest , the CAMP fire that burned the city of Paradise to the ground and killed over 80 or more people.  I was working a nursing home in Chico when we got notified that they were evacuating a nursing home, a retirement home the cities hospital.   They were inquiring how many of the half dozen care homes and the main hospital  had extra beds.  The nursing home up there was evacuating out the front door as the fire was b urning the back part.  About a quarter of our own staff lived in Paradise and surrounding areas. They were put up in the local hotels nearby.   The smoke was so bad that it completely blocked out the sun.

All senior assisted living homes and nursing homes should all be required by federal/state/city to have an emergency evacuation training program.  This includes the facilities having onsite emergency preparedness programs to have their bug out bags to include their money/jewelry, IDs, passport, medical cards,SSN card, emergency necklace or bracelet that states if they are diabetic,asthma (med condition that require to have their prescribed meds with them at all times. extra emergency prescriptions, prescription glasses, doctor/nurse contacts info, clinic and/or hospital they usually go to and address/phone#/email of their emergency contact family members.  A city bus will be provided for these facilities which will bring them to a pre-designated location such as a red cross/fema emergency shelter or another senior assisted home or nursing home or some on a diff. bus that needs to go to an actual hospital because of their highly vulnerable medical condition whereas a healthcare aide or nurse has to be nearby to check on them.  Also, if family members decides they will pick them up and bring them back to a family members home to look after during the emergency.

I miss my Uncle George (RIP) but I'm glad he didn't have to see this devastation. 

Anyone that's lived in Altadena/Pasadena for any length of time is probably familiar with my Uncle George (he was always in the local newspapers). 
He was the boys basketball coach for Pasadena High School & then Pasadena Community College. 
He's also in the Pasadena Sports Hall of Fame.

It didn't matter if it was 90¬∞.  
At Christmas when we'd gather in the living room to open presents, Uncle George would get in the Christmas Spirit! 
He'd wear a Christmas Sweater and build a fire in the fireplace (which was funny when the rest of us were wearing tank tops & shorts LOL).

I have 61 years of memories, good times & holidays spent in that house.  
I'm absolutely heartbroken.   üíî

Newsom has utterly failed to protect Californians from the ever-worsening wildfire crisis. Year after year, communities are decimated while Newsom pours billions into ridiculous vanity projects‚Äîlike the bullet train to nowhere‚Äîinstead of addressing the very real and urgent safety needs of the people he‚Äôs supposed to serve. While he chases headlines, Californians are left with nothing but ashes and shattered lives.

Practical solutions‚Äîlike widening fire roads to ensure safer evacuations and creating temporary refuge areas for displaced families‚Äîhave been sitting on the table for decades. Decades. And what has Newsom done? Nothing. His inaction, despite over 25 years of clear warnings, is not just negligent; it‚Äôs outright disgraceful.

Even worse, critical public safety funding continues to be deprioritized. Seven months before the uncontrolled Palisades Fire in Los Angeles, the city's fire department budget for this fiscal year was slashed by more than $17.5 million, according to records. Instead of strengthening frontline defenses, resources are being diverted elsewhere. Mayor Karen Bass, in signing the City of Los Angeles' budget for the 2024-2025 fiscal year, further highlighted how misplaced priorities are contributing to the wildfire crisis.

To the families who have lost everything‚Äîyour homes, your loved ones, your futures‚Äîyou deserve leaders who actually care about your survival, not ones obsessed with their political legacy. Newsom‚Äôs empty promises and grossly misplaced priorities show a staggering disregard for the very people he was elected to protect.

Governor Newsom, your failure is killing people. Californians are dying, and you‚Äôre too busy grandstanding to do anything meaningful. Stop ignoring basic common sense. Stop wasting time and resources on pipe dreams. Start doing your job‚Äîor step aside for someone who will. FK I can do a better job! Enough is enough.
